next.title: Visible light filters: Exploring Spiral Galaxies

contents.content:
Some galaxies are very distantâ€”so distant that their light, because of cosmological redshift, is detectable only at infrared wavelengths.

To quickly spot the most distant galaxies, a color composite image can be made using at least one infrared filter. The image obtained from the filter that transmits the light with the shortest wavelengths is colorized blue, and the image from the filter that transmits the light with the longest (infrared) wavelengths is colorized red. The color image at the right was made by combining all three filtered images and shows the most distant galaxies in a very red-orange color, because they are brightest at very long wavelengths.
Image colorized by T.A. Rector (University of Alaska Anchorage) and CTIO/NOAO/NSF.
